item.title: Test Tube Aliens
item.description:
Test Tube Aliens ðŸ”—

This entry details the Test Tube Aliens toy line, including their fictional backstory, the toy’s features, and how it functions.

Story ðŸ”—

The narrative revolves around two factions of aliens: the “good” aliens from the dying planet Naratuko, seeking a new home, and the “evil” aliens responsible for their planet’s destruction, pursuing them across the universe. The good aliens reverted to a pre-birth state to escape, sacrificing strength for intelligence. Initially, the story presents a clear good vs. evil dynamic. However, a later plot twist reveals that all the original aliens are actually evil, with the “X series” aliens being the true good guys. The evil aliens’ plan involves being discarded in bins after appearing dead, allowing them to infiltrate and take over bodies of water. This led to the release of a “Pure Evil” series.

The toy itself ðŸ”—

The toy consists of a test tube containing a white cocoon or chrysalis. Adding water dissolves the cocoon, revealing an infant alien. The alien’s “heart,” indicated by flashing lights, begins to beat, signifying it is “alive.” The alien requires feeding with “Sloog” (a white powder mixed with water) for the first few days, after which it can survive on tap water. Maintaining the alien’s health involves a 12-hour light/dark cycle. The alien reacts to improper conditions, flashing green for too much water and orange for too little. If neglected, the alien will “die,” rendering the toy unusable. Some owners have reported lifespans of seven to nine months. The toy also interacted with a now-defunct website where users could induce coma or panic modes and check the alien’s age and health. A picture of Kurion, a good alien, is included.

How it works ðŸ”—

The alien’s body contains polyacrylamide, a polymer that expands when it absorbs water. The “Sloog” contains a weak acid that slows this expansion, creating the illusion of growth over several days. The alien senses the acid’s presence through conductivity measurements via electrodes on its antenna and head. These electrodes also detect water levels, with the alien being “healthy” only when the water is between the antenna and head electrodes. Website interaction was achieved through a light detector in the alien’s head, responding to flashes from the “web portal” on the Test Tube Aliens website. This light detector also tracked light and dark exposure.
